title: Sweet on You
blurb: Sugary tones and affectionate motifs entwine, inviting reflection on modern sweetness amid global influences, in Sambuu’s energetic style.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. His works balance bold graphic elements with subtle cultural commentary, creating energetic compositions that invite viewers to reflect on global influences through a whimsical lens. Zayasaikhan Sambuu was born in 1975 in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, and lives and works there. He received his education at the Mongolian University of Arts and Culture.

title: Candy Girl
blurb: A candy-hued figure pops with playful energy, fusing Mongolian motifs with consumerist whimsy to explore identity in a vibrant, graphic narrative.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. title: Candy Girl 2
blurb: Sequel to the series, this piece layers sweet colors and bold forms, commenting on cultural contrasts through Sambuu’s signature pop-traditional blend.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. title: Cosmic Lotus Moth
medium: Archival pigment inks on cotton rag paper with salt crystals, gold leaf, and color pencil
blurb: Blending lotus blooms with moth forms in a starry cosmos, this work imagines fluid connections between earthly flora and celestial realms, inspired by 19th-century naturalists to fluctuate between microcosmic details and macroscopic wonders. Framed dimensions: 63.5 × 53.5 × 3.1 cm.
artist_bio: Christine Nguyen’s work draws on nature, science, and the cosmos, imagining fluid connections between ocean depths and outer space through an organic prism. Her practice, inspired by 19th-century naturalists like Ernst Haeckel and Anna Atkins, extracts curiosities from the natural world to create meditative, micro-macroscopic visions blending biology, philosophy, and mystery. Nguyen was born in 1977 in Mountain View, California, and resides in Aurora, Colorado, and Long Beach, California. She received her BFA from California State University, Long Beach, and her MFA from the University of California, Irvine. Nguyen has had solo exhibitions tied to residencies at Montello Foundation, NV, and Pacific Bonsai Museum, WA. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the J. Paul Getty Museum and Armand Hammer Museum, with works in collections including the Getty Research Institute and Long Beach Museum of Art.

title: Cosmic Rabbit Light
medium: Mixed media on Mylar with overlaid translucent layers
blurb: Mixed media on Mylar with overlaid translucent layers. Drawing on lunar mythology, the rabbit appears as a quiet alchemist bridging earth and celestial cycles. It drifts through layered atmospheres, trailing a comet-like trace that evokes timeless motion. Nguyen’s translucent Mylar creates dimensional suspension: forms hover and shift with viewer position and light, emphasizing impermanence. The rabbit symbolizes gentleness, intuition, and rebirth in a light-infused cosmology of memory and transformation.
artist_bio: Christine Nguyen’s work draws on nature, science, and the cosmos, imagining fluid connections between ocean depths and outer space through an organic prism. Her practice, inspired by 19th-century naturalists like Ernst Haeckel and Anna Atkins, extracts curiosities from the natural world to create meditative, micro-macroscopic visions blending biology, philosophy, and mystery. title: Cosmic Owl Light
medium: Mixed media on Mylar with overlaid translucent layers
blurb: Mixed media on Mylar with overlaid translucent layers. The owl emerges as a nocturnal guardian in a luminous, shifting field, embodying wisdom and thresholds between clarity and obscurity. Nguyen stacks Mylar layers for drifting marks and symbols, unfolding gradually with light to reveal hidden details. Meditative rather than illustrative, it metaphors perception as quiet and expansive, with the owl listening in perpetual flux.
artist_bio: Christine Nguyen’s work draws on nature, science, and the cosmos, imagining fluid connections between ocean depths and outer space through an organic prism. Her practice, inspired by 19th-century naturalists like Ernst Haeckel and Anna Atkins, extracts curiosities from the natural world to create meditative, micro-macroscopic visions blending biology, philosophy, and mystery. title: Cosmic Blue Flower Light
medium: Mixed media on Mylar with overlaid translucent layers
blurb: Mixed media on Mylar with overlaid translucent layers. The flower radiates as a cosmic axis, expanding like a mandala or stellar burst in energetic growth across light and time. Nguyen’s layered Mylar blends structure and atmosphere: translucent fields and particles evoke continuous emergence. Rooted yet weightless, it symbolizes inner luminosity and renewal, inviting contemplation of gentle, ongoing cycles.
artist_bio: Christine Nguyen’s work draws on nature, science, and the cosmos, imagining fluid connections between ocean depths and outer space through an organic prism. Her practice, inspired by 19th-century naturalists like Ernst Haeckel and Anna Atkins, extracts curiosities from the natural world to create meditative, micro-macroscopic visions blending biology, philosophy, and mystery. title: Cloud Euphoria
blurb: Billowing clouds swirl in euphoric abstraction, inspired by en plein air sessions to capture fleeting atmospheric joy, blending perception with emotional universality for an immersive skyward gaze.
artist_bio: Lily Prince’s plein air-inspired works translate observational landscapes into personal expressions of universal significance, viewing beauty as a form of protest amid environmental and societal challenges. Combining direct perception, memory, and aspiration, her watercolor, gouache, and oil pastel pieces create fresh vistas that feel familiar yet surprising, drawing from terrains like the American West, Italy, and New York’s Hudson Valley. Prince was born in 1962 and is based in New York and the Hudson Valley. She received her BFA from Rhode Island School of Design and her MFA from Bard College, with a residency at Skowhegan. Prince has had solo exhibitions linked to residencies at Olana and BAU Institute, Italy. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the New Museum, NY; Galerie Huit, Arles, France; and Draftsmen’s Congress at The New Museum.

title: Morning
blurb: Depicting the fresh glow of dawn’s light on terrain, this piece translates direct perception into aspirational space, merging Italian, Irish, and American West influences for an uplifting narrative of renewal.
artist_bio: Lily Prince’s plein air-inspired works translate observational landscapes into personal expressions of universal significance, viewing beauty as a form of protest amid environmental and societal challenges. title: Evening
medium: Acrylic on 300 lb. paper, white frame
blurb: This watercolor captures the softening hues of dusk in a landscape vista, blending plein air observation with memory to evoke a sense of peaceful transition, positioning beauty as a subtle protest against environmental flux. Framed dimensions: 63 × 68 × 3 cm.
artist_bio: Lily Prince’s plein air-inspired works translate observational landscapes into personal expressions of universal significance, viewing beauty as a form of protest amid environmental and societal challenges.
